language.description:
Canonical source(s): Giron 2008:419-439 Epps 2008
Classification comment: There are some lexical paralles with Nadahup and Kakua-Nukak  Giron 2008:419-439 but these are hardly conclusive of a genetic relation. The pronouns, morphology and bulk of the vocabulary have no cognates.


Epps, Patience. (2008) A grammar of Hup (Mouton Grammar Library 43). Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.  

Giron, Jesus Mario. (2008) Una gramatica del W~ans"oj"ot (Puinave). Amsterdam: Vrije Universiteit doctoral dissertation.

iso_retirement.comment:
Angaité and Sanapaná are different on all of the above criteria. Indeed, the two languages are not mutually intelligible, and there is a clear ethnoliguistic distinction.
The existing code element does not represent a major language. The Sanapaná and Angaité languages are of equal standing in relation to each other and to the other languages of the family. For example, comparing the differences between Angaité and Sanapaná with those between Angaité and Enxet, the classification of the two languages in a single code element is clearly arbitrary.
iso_retirement.name: Sanapaná

iso_retirement.comment: The lexical similarity of Ishkashimi and Sanglechi is 70%. Comprehension testing showed that intelligibility between the two speech varieties is marginal, although the Sanglechi understand Ishkashimi slightly better than vice versa. No common writing system and no common literature exists for the two speech varieties since they are oral languages. The speakers of Ishkashimi and Sanglechi do not perceive themselves to speak the same language nor to have the same ethnolinguistic identity.
iso_retirement.name: Sanglechi-Ishkashimi
